wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the quantumbotx system. Explain its purpose as an AI-powered modular trading bot platform integrated with MetaTrader 5, designed for automated trading, backtesting, and portfolio monitoring. Describe the high-level architecture including the Flask-based web interface, backend logic in Python, and frontend in JavaScript/CSS. Document the technology stack: Flask, MetaTrader5, pandas, pandas_ta, and SQLite. Illustrate the component relationships between core modules (bots, strategies, backtesting, MT5, database) and how they interact through API routes. Provide a conceptual overview suitable for beginners while including technical depth for developers, such as the MVC-like separation and threading model. Include practical examples of system workflows like bot creation and backtesting. Address key architectural decisions and their implications on scalability and maintainability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the quantumbotx application. Describe the high-level design as a modular Flask-based trading platform with separation between frontend (HTML/CSS/JS), backend logic (Python), and external MT5 integration. Explain the MVC-like architectural pattern with routes handling HTTP requests, core services managing business logic, and database/MT5 modules handling data persistence and execution. Detail key architectural components: Flask application factory, thread-based bot execution, strategy plugin system, and RESTful API layer. Illustrate component interactions including request flow from UI to API to bot/strategy layers, and real-time data flow from MT5 to dashboard. Include system context diagram showing user, web interface, application core, database, and MetaTrader 5 terminal. Address architectural decisions such as using threading over async for bot management, SQLite for lightweight persistence, and strategy registry pattern for extensibility. Discuss scalability limitations and potential improvements like containerization, message queues, or distributed backtesting.

wiki_catalogs.name: Application Factory Pattern
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Flask application factory pattern implemented in core/__init__.py. Explain how the create_app() function initializes the Flask application with proper configuration, registers blueprints from the routes module, sets up logging via core.utils.logger, and ensures separation of concerns. Detail the role of instance folders, environment-based configuration loading, and extension initialization. Illustrate how this pattern enables testability, modularity, and multiple application instances if needed. Include code examples showing blueprint registration for api_bots, api_backtest, and other route modules. Discuss best practices followed in the implementation and how it supports extensibility for future features.

wiki_catalogs.name: Trading Bot Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the TradingBot class architecture in quantumbotx. Explain its object-oriented design, core attributes (symbol, strategy, lot_size, mt5_connection), and thread-safe state management (running, paused, stopped). Detail the run() method's infinite loop structure, tick processing, and integration with the strategy's signal generation. Document how the bot handles order execution via MT5, including error retry logic and trade confirmation. Include a code example showing the instantiation of a TradingBot with a MA Crossover strategy. Illustrate the interaction between the bot's lifecycle methods (start(), stop(), pause()) and threading controls. Address performance considerations for low-latency signal processing and memory usage during extended operation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Base Strategy Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the BaseStrategy abstract class in quantumbotx. Explain its role as the foundation for all trading strategies, detailing the required methods such as `init`, `on_tick`, and `get_params`. Document the lifecycle of a strategy from initialization to signal generation. Describe how the abstract base class enforces contract compliance across concrete implementations. Provide code examples showing method signatures and expected behavior. Explain integration points with the TradingBot and market data pipeline. Include best practices for exception handling, state management, and performance optimization within strategy execution. Address common implementation errors and debugging techniques when extending BaseStrategy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backtesting Methodology
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the backtesting methodology implemented in engine.py. Explain the event-driven simulation model used for historical market replay, including tick-level vs. candle-based processing. Document how historical price data is loaded and synchronized across multiple timeframes and symbols. Describe the order execution simulation logic, including slippage modeling, commission calculation, and partial fill handling. Detail the position and portfolio tracking mechanism during simulation. Include code examples showing the core loop in engine.py, with emphasis on strategy invocation, signal generation, and trade execution simulation. Explain the assumptions and limitations of the model, such as no market impact and perfect liquidity. Provide best practices for configuring realistic trading cost parameters.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bots API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create RESTful API documentation for the Bots API endpoints in the quantumbotx application. Document all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) for bot creation, retrieval, starting, stopping, and deletion. Specify URL patterns such as /api/bots and /api/bots/<bot_id>, including path parameters and their constraints. Detail request body schemas for bot configuration including strategy_type, symbol, timeframe, lot_size, and risk_management settings. Define response formats for success and error cases, including newly created bot IDs and status updates. Include authentication requirements using API keys or session tokens. Provide JSON examples for creating a MA Crossover bot and starting a QuantumBotX Hybrid strategy. List all possible status codes (200, 201, 400, 401, 404, 500) with descriptions. Add sample curl commands for key operations. Explain validation rules for parameters and how errors are returned. Document rate limiting policies if applicable and any dependencies on MT5 connection status.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bots Table Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the bots table in the quantumbotx database. Detail all fields including id, name, symbol, strategy, parameters, status, created_at, updated_at, and user_id. Document data types, constraints (NOT NULL, UNIQUE), primary key (id), and foreign key relationship to users table. Explain business rules such as valid status transitions (stopped, running, paused) and parameter storage format (JSON). Include sample records showing different bot configurations. Describe query patterns used in the application for retrieving active bots, filtering by strategy, or searching by name. Document indexing strategy on status and user_id for performance optimization. Address data integrity considerations and validation logic enforced at both application and database levels.

wiki_catalogs.name: UI Templates
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for each HTML template used in the quantumbotx frontend. Explain the purpose and functionality of each page including index (landing/dashboard), trading_bots (bot management), backtesting (strategy simulation), portfolio (position tracking), profile (user settings), and auxiliary views like notifications and market-specific pages. Document template inheritance from base.html, including block definitions and reusable components. Describe form structures, data display tables, and dynamic content placeholders. Include information on error templates (404, 500) and their user experience considerations. Provide guidance on modifying templates for customization and adding new views while maintaining consistency with existing design patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Connection Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the MT5 connection management system in quantumbotx. Explain how the application initializes and authenticates with the MetaTrader 5 terminal using the MetaTrader5 Python package. Document the startup sequence in run.py that establishes the initial connection, including environment variable configuration for account credentials and server details. Detail the reconnection logic implemented to handle disconnections or session timeouts. Describe the role of core/utils/mt5.py in encapsulating connection health checks and recovery procedures. Provide code examples showing safe connect/disconnect patterns, error handling for common connection failures (e.g., invalid credentials, server unreachable), and best practices for managing connection state across multiple trading bots. Include performance considerations for minimizing connection overhead and avoiding rate limits.

wiki_catalogs.name: Adding New Trading Strategies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for creating custom trading strategies in the quantumbotx system. Explain how to extend the BaseStrategy class by implementing the required methods: `init`, `on_tick`, and `on_bar`. Provide step-by-step instructions for registering a new strategy in the STRATEGY_MAP dictionary within strategy_map.py. Include a complete code example of a new strategy implementation, such as a 'Moving Average Envelope' strategy, demonstrating proper parameter handling, signal generation logic, and integration with the bot execution loop. Document best practices for strategy design including risk management checks, parameter validation using utils/validation.py, and logging via utils/logger.py. Explain how to test new strategies using the backtesting engine in core/backtesting/engine.py and how to validate outputs against historical data. Address common pitfalls such as overfitting, lookahead bias, and thread safety considerations when accessing shared data. Include performance optimization tips for computationally intensive calculations using pandas_ta and numpy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Ollama Client Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Ollama client implementation in ollama_client.py. Explain the class structure, initialization parameters, and connection handling for local LLMs. Document the request/response cycle, including HTTP configuration, timeout handling, and error resilience. Detail the methods for generating responses, streaming support, and model parameter customization (temperature, top_p, etc.). Provide code examples showing how the client sends prompts and parses responses. Explain integration with the broader AI utility layer and how it abstracts LLM interactions. Address thread safety considerations and performance implications of synchronous API calls in real-time trading contexts. Include guidance on debugging connectivity issues and validating model outputs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Trading Bot System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Trading Bot system in quantumbotx. Explain the architecture and lifecycle of the TradingBot class, including initialization, thread-based execution loop, strategy loading via STRATEGY_MAP, signal generation, and trade execution through MT5 integration. Document configuration parameters such as symbol, timeframe, strategy type, and risk settings. Provide code examples showing bot creation, starting/stopping mechanisms, and interaction with the controller for managing active bots. Illustrate how the bot handles real-time market data streaming, error recovery, and state persistence. Address common issues like thread safety when accessing shared resources, graceful shutdown procedures, and synchronization between bot instances and the API layer. Include performance considerations for running multiple concurrent bots and best practices for resource management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bot Lifecycle Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Bot Lifecycle Management workflow in quantumbotx. Explain the complete lifecycle of a trading bot: creation (via POST /api/bots), configuration (parameter validation, strategy mapping, risk settings), starting (thread initialization, MT5 connection check, order execution readiness), running state (heartbeat monitoring, position synchronization), stopping (graceful shutdown, open position handling), and deletion (resource cleanup, database removal). Reference specific code implementations such as the create_bot() function in api_bots.py that validates payload using validate_bot_config(), the controller's role in managing active_bots dictionary, and how TradingBot class in trading_bot.py handles threading and state transitions. Include sequence diagrams showing interaction between frontend, API endpoint, BotController, and MT5 interface. Document error handling scenarios like invalid strategy name, MT5 disconnection on start, or database write failure during creation. Provide troubleshooting tips for common issues such as bots failing to start due to incorrect symbol configuration or thread conflicts. Highlight integration points with database (bot persistence) and MT5 (trading capability check).

wiki_catalogs.name: Bot Management System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Bot Management System, focusing on the TradingBot class implementation in core/bots/trading_bot.py. Explain its thread-based execution model, lifecycle management (start, stop, pause), and interaction with strategy and MT5 modules. Document how the controller in core/bots/controller.py handles bot creation, persistence, and state management. Illustrate with code examples how API routes in core/routes/api_bots.py delegate to controller methods. Include configuration parameters, error handling during execution, and concurrency considerations. Address common issues such as bot freezing, unresponsive states, and recovery strategies. Highlight extensibility points for custom bot behaviors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Trades Table Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the trades table in the quantumbotx database. Detail each field: id (primary key), bot_id (foreign key to bots), symbol (trading pair), trade_type (buy/sell), volume (lot size), price (entry price), sl (stop loss), tp (take profit), open_time, close_time, profit (calculated PnL), and status (open/closed/failed). Explain the foreign key relationship with the bots table and indexing strategy on bot_id, symbol, and open_time for query performance. Document how this table stores historical trade data for backtesting validation and performance analytics. Provide a sample record of a completed long trade with profit calculation. Describe common queries used to aggregate win rate, average holding time, and total PnL per bot. Include data retention policies and archiving considerations for large-scale deployments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Base Strategy Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the BaseStrategy abstract class in quantumbotx. Explain its role as the foundational contract for all trading strategies, detailing required methods such as `initialize()`, `generate_signal()`, and `get_parameters()`. Document how this interface enforces consistency across strategy implementations and enables polymorphic behavior in the bot execution engine. Illustrate the integration with the STRATEGY_MAP dictionary for dynamic strategy instantiation based on user configuration. Include code examples showing method signatures, exception handling, and lifecycle management. Explain how the base class interacts with market data (pandas DataFrames), technical indicators (via pandas_ta), and risk management utilities. Address design decisions behind the abstract methods and provide guidance on proper inheritance patterns. Include best practices for maintaining state, handling missing data, and ensuring thread safety in derived classes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Base Strategy Interface
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the BaseStrategy abstract class in core/strategies/base_strategy.py. Explain its role as the foundation of the strategy pattern implementation, including the required methods such as __init__ and execute. Document the interface contract that all concrete strategies must adhere to, including parameter initialization, market data input (pandas DataFrame), and signal output format (BUY, SELL, HOLD). Describe how the base class integrates with the broader system, including access to configuration, risk parameters, and logging. Provide code examples showing how inherited strategies extend the base class and override key methods. Discuss abstract method enforcement, error handling patterns, and lifecycle management during bot execution. Address common implementation mistakes and debugging techniques when extending BaseStrategy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bots API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create RESTful API documentation for the Bots API endpoints. Document all HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) for bot management operations including create, start, stop, delete, and list bots. Specify request body schema for bot configuration including strategy type, symbol, timeframe, and risk parameters. Detail response formats with bot status, active trades, and performance metrics. Explain authentication via session or API key, input validation using core.utils.validation, and error responses for invalid configurations or duplicate names. Include curl examples for creating a MA Crossover bot and starting/stopping an existing bot. Describe how api_bots.py routes delegate to controller functions in controller.py for business logic execution. Address threading implications and race conditions in bot state changes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bollinger Reversion Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Bollinger Reversion strategy. Explain its mean-reversion trading logic that generates buy/sell signals when price touches or crosses the upper and lower Bollinger Bands. Detail the calculation of bands using pandas_ta with configurable window size and standard deviation multiplier. Describe how the strategy evaluates the distance from the middle band (SMA) to determine position sizing and signal strength. Document integration with volume indicators for confirmation to reduce false signals. Include configuration parameters such as entry thresholds, exit conditions, and risk controls. Provide a concrete example from the code showing signal generation on price deviation. Illustrate how it overrides the execute method from BaseStrategy and interacts with market data via MT5 utilities. Address common issues like whipsaw in volatile markets and band repainting due to lookback window changes. Offer best practices for parameter tuning and risk management, including stop-loss placement and position scaling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Indonesian AI Trading Mentor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Indonesian AI Trading Mentor system. Document its purpose, implementation details, API interfaces, and integration patterns. Include practical examples and troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Mentor Database Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the AI Mentor database schema. Document the purpose, structure, and relationships of the trading_sessions, ai_mentor_reports, and daily_trading_data tables. Include field descriptions, data types, and example queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Trading Sessions Table
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the trading_sessions table. Document its purpose, fields, and role in the AI mentor system. Include examples of how session data is created and updated.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Mentor Reports Table
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the ai_mentor_reports table. Document its purpose, fields, and relationship to trading sessions. Include examples of how reports are generated and stored.

wiki_catalogs.name: Daily Trading Data Table
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the daily_trading_data table. Document its purpose, fields, and role in providing data for AI analysis. Include examples of how trade data is logged and retrieved.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Mentor Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the AI mentor integration. Document how the trading bot logs data for AI analysis, the data flow between components, and the timing of data collection.

wiki_catalogs.name: Holiday Integration Framework
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the Holiday Integration Framework. Document its purpose, implementation details, API interfaces, and integration patterns. Include practical examples and troubleshooting guidance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on initial setup and execution of the quantumbotx application. Provide step-by-step installation instructions including Python environment setup, dependency installation via pip from requirements.txt, and Node.js packages via package.json. Detail configuration requirements such as setting up .env file with MT5 credentials and database paths. Explain how to initialize the database using init_db.py. Document the process to start the Flask application through run.py, including common startup commands and expected output. Include troubleshooting tips for common setup issues like missing dependencies, MT5 terminal connectivity problems, or database initialization errors. Make this guide beginner-friendly with clear, sequential steps while also providing advanced configuration options for experienced users.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the quantumbotx technology stack. Document each core technology and its role: Flask (web framework and API server), MetaTrader5 (trading execution and market data), pandas (data manipulation for backtesting and analysis), pandas_ta (technical indicator calculations), SQLite (persistent storage for bot configurations and trade history), JavaScript (frontend interactivity), and CSS (UI styling). Explain version compatibility requirements and installation procedures for each dependency. Detail how these technologies integrate: Flask serving templates and API endpoints, pandas DataFrames processing OHLC data for strategies, and MT5 Python package enabling automated trading. Include practical examples of technology usage patterns such as using pandas_ta to calculate Bollinger Bands in strategies or Flask blueprints to organize API routes. Address performance considerations like memory usage when loading large historical datasets and best practices for dependency management using virtual environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Modular Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on the modular architecture of quantumbotx, focusing on the separation of concerns across core modules: bots, strategies, database, MT5 integration, routes, and utilities. Explain how each module encapsulates specific responsibilities and interacts through well-defined interfaces. Use examples from the codebase to show how the TradingBot class in core/bots/trading_bot.py uses strategy instances and MT5 trade execution, while relying on database queries for persistence. Highlight how route handlers delegate to controller logic rather than containing business rules directly. Discuss the benefits of this modularity for maintainability, testing, and feature extension. Address how utility functions in core/utils support cross-cutting concerns like validation, logging, and symbol management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Bot Lifecycle Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the trading bot lifecycle management system. Thoroughly explain the start(), stop(), and pause() methods in the TradingBot class, including thread synchronization mechanisms and graceful shutdown procedures. Document how the BotController in controller.py manages the global active_bots dictionary, ensures thread-safe access, and provides centralized lifecycle operations. Include examples from the code showing how API calls trigger bot creation and termination through the controller. Explain the cleanup process for open positions and resource deallocation during shutdown. Address common issues such as race conditions during bot deletion and zombie thread prevention. Provide best practices for monitoring bot health and implementing heartbeat checks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strategy Registration System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the STRATEGY_MAP dictionary in strategy_map.py that enables dynamic strategy loading in quantumbotx. Explain how the mapping between string identifiers and strategy classes facilitates runtime instantiation via configuration. Document the import structure and module-level references required for proper registration. Provide examples of valid strategy configurations in bot setup. Explain how the system resolves strategy names during bot creation and handles invalid or missing strategy keys. Include guidance on ensuring thread-safe access to the strategy map and avoiding circular imports. Address common issues such as 'strategy not found' errors and module loading failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Performance Metrics
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the performance metrics calculated by the backtesting engine. Document each metric including total return, annualized return, Sharpe ratio, Sortino ratio, maximum drawdown, win rate, profit factor, and expectancy. Explain the mathematical formulas used and their financial significance in evaluating strategy robustness. Include code examples from engine.py showing how metrics are computed from trade history and equity curve data. Describe how risk-adjusted returns are calculated and interpreted. Provide guidance on benchmarking performance against baseline strategies. Address common pitfalls in performance evaluation, such as overfitting and look-ahead bias. Include visualization examples from backtesting_analyzer.html that display these metrics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backtesting API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive RESTful API documentation for the Backtesting API in quantumbotx. Document endpoints for initiating backtests, retrieving historical results, and analyzing performance metrics. Specify HTTP methods and routes like /api/backtest and /api/backtest/history. Detail request parameters including strategy_type, symbol, timeframe, date range, initial_balance, and custom strategy parameters in JSON format. Define response schema with fields such as total_return, sharpe_ratio, max_drawdown, trade_count, and equity_curve data points. Include authentication and required headers. Provide example requests for running a Bollinger Squeeze backtest and retrieving results. Document all status codes and error responses (e.g., invalid date range, unsupported strategy). Include sample curl commands and Postman examples. Explain data validation rules, parameter constraints, and how missing optional parameters are handled. Describe pagination for history endpoints and any rate limiting policies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strategies Configuration Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the strategies configuration storage in the quantumbotx database. Focus on the strategies table schema including fields like id, name, description, default_parameters, category, and is_active. Document data types, constraints, and the role of this table in supporting the strategy plugin architecture. Explain how default_parameters field (JSON) stores template values for strategy initialization and its relationship with bot creation workflow. Provide examples of default parameter structures for MA Crossover, RSI Crossover, and Bollinger Bands strategies. Describe how the application queries this table to populate strategy selection menus in the UI. Include performance considerations for JSON field indexing and query efficiency when filtering by category or active status.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling and CSS Assets
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the CSS architecture in quantumbotx. Analyze and document the structure of style.css as the global stylesheet and dashboard.css for page-specific styling. Detail the CSS organization, class naming conventions, layout system, and responsive design implementation. Document color schemes, typography, spacing system, and UI component styles (buttons, cards, forms). Explain media queries and mobile responsiveness approach. Provide guidance on extending the stylesheet, creating new themes, and maintaining visual consistency. Include information on CSS dependencies and optimization practices used in the project.

wiki_catalogs.name: Market Data Access
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the market data access functionality in quantumbotx's MT5 integration. Explain how the application retrieves historical price data, symbol lists, and real-time quotes from MetaTrader 5 using the copy_rates_range, symbols_get, and account_info functions. Document the data transformation process from MT5's native format to pandas DataFrames for strategy consumption. Detail the filtering and preprocessing logic in core/utils/mt5.py for cleaning and normalizing market data. Provide examples from core/routes/api_forex.py and api_stocks.py showing how frontend requests trigger data retrieval. Address common issues like missing data, timezone mismatches, and symbol availability. Include performance optimization techniques such as caching, batch requests, and efficient time range selection to minimize API load and improve response times.

wiki_catalogs.name: Extending API Endpoints
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for adding new RESTful API endpoints to the quantumbotx application. Detail the process of creating a new Flask blueprint following the existing pattern in core/routes/. Explain how to register the blueprint in the create_app factory function in core/__init__.py. Provide a concrete example of implementing a new endpoint group for managing watchlists, including route definitions for GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE operations. Document proper request validation using Flask's request object and response formatting using jsonify. Include security considerations such as input sanitization, authentication checks using existing decorators, and rate limiting if applicable. Show how to integrate with backend services and handle errors gracefully with standardized error responses. Demonstrate how to document the new endpoints using OpenAPI/Swagger conventions if available. Include testing guidance for writing unit tests for the new endpoints using Flask's test client and example test cases. Reference existing endpoints in api_bots.py and api_backtest.py as implementation models.

wiki_catalogs.name: AI Utility Integration Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the AI utility functions that bridge trading logic and AI models. Explain how ai.py provides high-level interfaces for strategy decision support using natural language processing. Document ollama.py's role in formatting prompts, managing context windows, and parsing structured responses from the Ollama client. Detail the prompt engineering patterns used for market analysis, sentiment interpretation, and trade signal generation. Include examples of how unstructured AI output is validated and converted into actionable trading parameters. Explain error handling for malformed responses and fallback mechanisms. Address configuration management for AI model selection and response constraints. Provide best practices for maintaining determinism in AI-assisted trading decisions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strategy Framework
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Strategy Framework in quantumbotx. Explain the BaseStrategy abstract class interface, including required methods like `generate_signal()` and `initialize()`, and how concrete strategies inherit and implement this contract. Document the strategy registration mechanism via STRATEGY_MAP and dynamic instantiation from configuration. Provide in-depth coverage of key strategies: MA Crossover (dual moving average logic), RSI Crossover (momentum-based thresholds), Bollinger Reversion/Squeeze (volatility band analysis), Ichimoku Cloud (trend and support/resistance), and QuantumbotX Hybrid (multi-indicator fusion). Include code examples showing signal calculation, parameter tuning, and backtesting compatibility. Illustrate how strategies consume market data via pandas DataFrames and integrate with technical indicators from pandas_ta. Address common development challenges such as overfitting, parameter optimization, and handling edge cases in signal generation. Include best practices for creating custom strategies and ensuring thread-safe operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backtesting Workflow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Backtesting Workflow in quantumbotx. Thoroughly explain the process flow: strategy selection (via STRATEGY_MAP), parameter input (timeframe, symbol, strategy-specific settings), validation (using validate_backtest_params()), simulation execution in BacktestEngine, historical data fetching from MT5, trade signal generation, position tracking, and performance metric calculation (Sharpe ratio, max drawdown, win rate). Use concrete examples from code, such as how run_backtest() in api_backtest.py orchestrates the workflow by instantiating BacktestEngine and passing validated parameters. Document how the engine simulates trades using bar-by-bar replay and calculates equity curves. Include a sequence diagram showing interactions between frontend, API, engine, strategy, and market data utilities. Explain result interpretation including JSON output structure with metrics and trade logs. Address common issues like insufficient historical data, incorrect parameter types, or strategy exceptions during simulation, and provide debugging strategies such as enabling verbose logging. Highlight performance considerations for long backtests and recommendations for parameter optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strategy Framework
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Strategy Framework, centered on the BaseStrategy abstract class in core/strategies/base_strategy.py. Explain the interface contract, required methods (init, execute), and how concrete strategies like MA Crossover and RSI Crossover implement trading logic. Describe the strategy registration mechanism via STRATEGY_MAP and dynamic instantiation. Use real code examples to show signal generation, indicator usage with pandas_ta, and risk management patterns. Discuss how strategies interact with market data from MT5 and respond to price updates. Include guidance on backtesting compatibility and performance implications of different strategy designs. Address common development pitfalls and debugging techniques.

wiki_catalogs.name: Positions Table Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the positions table, which tracks real-time open positions managed by trading bots. Define fields: id (primary key), bot_id (linked to bot instance), symbol, trade_type, volume, price, sl, tp, open_time, current_price, unrealized_profit, and last_updated. Explain how this table reflects live market state synchronized with MT5 platform data via periodic updates. Highlight the one-to-many relationship with bots and the need for atomic updates during price synchronization. Document indexing on bot_id and symbol for fast dashboard rendering. Provide a sample record of an active EURUSD buy position with dynamic unrealized PnL. Describe how this table enables real-time portfolio monitoring and risk exposure calculations. Include concurrency handling during simultaneous position updates and strategies for minimizing database lock contention.

wiki_catalogs.name: MA Crossover Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the MA Crossover strategy implementation. Explain the dual moving average logic that compares short-term and long-term MAs to generate buy/sell signals, including parameter configuration for fast and slow window sizes. Document the signal generation algorithm, including crossover detection and trend confirmation logic. Provide examples of how the strategy processes OHLC data using pandas and calculates moving averages via pandas_ta. Illustrate integration with the backtesting engine and real-time trading loop. Include performance characteristics, optimal market conditions (trending markets), and common pitfalls like whipsaws in sideways markets. Show configuration examples, parameter tuning recommendations, and visualization of entry/exit points on price charts. Address edge cases such as NaN values during initialization and warm-up periods.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strategy Registration and Discovery
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the strategy registration mechanism implemented in core/strategies/strategy_map.py. Explain how the STRATEGY_MAP dictionary enables dynamic instantiation of strategy classes by mapping string identifiers to concrete class references. Document how this supports configuration-driven bot creation via API or UI inputs. Describe the import structure, class referencing, and case sensitivity considerations. Provide examples of how the trading bot controller uses this map to instantiate strategies at runtime. Discuss extensibility patterns for adding new strategies, including naming conventions and module import requirements. Address potential issues like circular imports, missing registrations, and case mismatches in configuration. Include best practices for maintaining the strategy map as the codebase grows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backtesting API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive API documentation for the Backtesting API. Detail the POST endpoint for initiating backtests with parameters such as strategy type, symbol, timeframe, date range, and capital. wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# QuantumBotX: Comprehensive Project Analysis

## 1. Project Introduction

QuantumBotX is an AI-powered modular trading bot designed for the MetaTrader 5 (MT5) platform. Built with Python and Flask, this sophisticated trading assistant combines technical analysis, automated trading execution, and comprehensive backtesting capabilities in a user-friendly web interface.

The primary goal of QuantumBotX is to provide traders with a flexible, powerful, and intelligent trading system that can adapt to different market conditions. The bot supports multiple trading strategies, offers real-time analysis through a live dashboard, and enables comprehensive backtesting against historical data with detailed performance metrics.

Targeted at both retail and professional traders, QuantumBotX caters to various trading styles including scalping, swing trading, and algorithmic strategy research. The modular architecture allows users to create and implement their own custom trading strategies while benefiting from built-in adaptive logic that can switch between different approaches based on market conditions.

## 2. Technical Architecture

QuantumBotX follows a modular, layered architecture with clear separation of concerns. The application is built around a Flask web server that serves as the API gateway and web interface, while integrating with the MetaTrader 5 platform for market data and trade execution.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Browser] --> B[Flask Web Server]
    B --> C[API Routes]
    C --> D[Bots Controller]
    D --> E[Trading Bot]
    E --> F[Trading Strategy]
    F --> G[Market Data]
    G --> H[MT5 Platform]
    E --> H
    D --> I[Database]
    C --> I
    C --> J[Backtesting Engine]
    J --> K[Historical Data]
```

The architecture consists of several key components:
- **Web Interface**: A responsive dashboard built with Flask, TailwindCSS, and Chart.js
- **API Layer**: RESTful endpoints for bot management, strategy configuration, and data retrieval
- **Business Logic**: Trading bots, strategies, and backtesting engine
- **Data Access**: SQLite database for persistence and configuration
- **External Integration**: MetaTrader 5 platform for market data and trade execution

The application follows the factory pattern for Flask application creation, with `create_app()` in `core/__init__.py` serving as the central entry point that configures the application instance and registers blueprints for different API routes.

## 3. Implementation Details

### Main Entry Points

The application is launched through `run.py`, which initializes the Flask application and establishes the connection to MetaTrader 5:

```python
# run.py
app = create_app()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    try:
        ACCOUNT = int(os.getenv('MT5_LOGIN'))
        PASSWORD = os.getenv('MT5_PASSWORD')
        SERVER = os.getenv('MT5_SERVER', 'MetaQuotes-Demo')
        if initialize_mt5(ACCOUNT, PASSWORD, SERVER):
            logging.info("Koneksi MT5 berhasil diinisialisasi dari run.py.")
            ambil_semua_bot()
            atexit.register(shutdown_app)
    except Exception as e:
        logging.critical(f"GAGAL total saat inisialisasi MT5 di run.py: {e}", exc_info=True)

    app.run(
        debug=os.getenv('FLASK_DEBUG', 'False').lower() == 'true',
        host=os.getenv('FLASK_HOST', '127.0.0.1'),
        port=int(os.getenv('FLASK_PORT', 5000)),
        use_reloader=False
    )
```

### Core Modules

The core functionality is organized into several modules within the `core` directory:

**Application Factory**: The `create_app()` function in `core/__init__.py` creates and configures the Flask application instance, registers blueprints for different API routes, and sets up logging:

```python
def create_app():
    app = Flask(
        __name__, 
        instance_relative_config=True,
        template_folder='../templates',
        static_folder='../static'
    )    
    app.config['SECRET_KEY'] = os.getenv('SECRET_KEY', 'your-secret-key-here')
    
    # Register blueprints
    from .routes.api_dashboard import api_dashboard
    from .routes.api_bots import api_bots
    # ... other imports
    app.register_blueprint(api_dashboard)
    app.register_blueprint(api_bots)
    # ... other registrations
    
    return app
```

### Integration Points

The application integrates with MetaTrader 5 through the `MetaTrader5` Python package, with utility functions in `core/utils/mt5.py` providing a clean interface:

```python
def get_rates_mt5(symbol: str, timeframe: int, count: int = 100):
    """Mengambil data harga historis (rates) dari MT5 dalam bentuk DataFrame."""
    try:
        rates = mt5.copy_rates_from_pos(symbol, timeframe, 0, count)
        if rates is None or len(rates) == 0:
            logger.warning(f"Gagal mengambil data harga untuk {symbol} (Timeframe: {timeframe}).")
            return pd.DataFrame()
        
        df = pd.DataFrame(rates)
        df['time'] = pd.to_datetime(df['time'], unit='s')
        df.set_index('time', inplace=True)
        return df
    except Exception as e:
        logger.error(f"Error saat get_rates_mt5 untuk {symbol}: {e}", exc_info=True)
        return pd.DataFrame()
```

## 4. Key Features

### Modular Strategy System

QuantumBotX implements a modular strategy system where trading strategies inherit from a base `BaseStrategy` class:

```python
class BaseStrategy(ABC):
    def __init__(self, bot_instance, params: dict = {}):
        self.bot = bot_instance
        self.params = params

    @abstractmethod
    def analyze(self, df):
        raise NotImplementedError("Setiap strategi harus mengimplementasikan metode `analyze(df)`.")
```

Strategies are registered in a central `STRATEGY_MAP` that allows dynamic strategy selection:

```python
STRATEGY_MAP = {
    'MA_CROSSOVER': MACrossoverStrategy,
    'QUANTUMBOTX_HYBRID': QuantumBotXHybridStrategy,
    'RSI_CROSSOVER': RSICrossoverStrategy,
    # ... other strategies
}
```

- [base_strategy.py](d:\dev\quantumbotx\core\strategies\base_strategy.py#L1-L29)
- [strategy_map.py](d:\dev\quantumbotx\core\strategies\strategy_map.py#L1-L28)

### Adaptive Hybrid Strategy

The QuantumBotX Hybrid strategy adapts to market conditions by switching between different approaches based on ADX (Average Directional Index) values:

```python
def analyze(self, df):
    adx_value = last[f'ADX_{adx_period}']
    
    if adx_value > adx_threshold: # Mode Trending
        # Use MA Crossover logic
        if is_uptrend and prev[f'SMA_{ma_fast_period}'] <= prev[f'SMA_{ma_slow_period}'] and last[f'SMA_{ma_fast_period}'] > last[f'SMA_{ma_slow_period}']:
            signal = "BUY"
    else: # Mode Ranging
        # Use Bollinger Bands logic
        if is_uptrend and last['low'] <= last[bbl_col]:
            signal = "BUY"
```

This adaptive approach allows the bot to perform well in both trending and ranging markets.

### Automated Trading Execution

The bot handles trade execution through the `mt5/trade.py` module, which includes sophisticated position management:

```python
def _handle_trade_signal(self, signal, position):
    """Menangani sinyal trading: membuka, menutup, atau tidak melakukan apa-apa."""
    if signal == 'BUY':
        if position and position.type == mt5.ORDER_TYPE_SELL:
            close_trade(position)
        if not position:
            place_trade(self.market_for_mt5, mt5.ORDER_TYPE_BUY, self.risk_percent, self.sl_pips, self.tp_pips, self.id)
```

The system automatically closes opposing positions before opening new ones, ensuring clean trade management.

### Bot Lifecycle Management

The bot controller manages the lifecycle of trading bots, handling creation, starting, stopping, and deletion:

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Initializing: create_bot
    Initializing --> Active: start_bot
    Active --> Paused: stop_bot
    Paused --> Active: start_bot
    Active --> Error: exception
    Error --> Paused: recover
    Paused --> [*]: delete_bot
```

The controller uses a dictionary to track active bot instances and ensures proper cleanup during shutdown:

active_bots = {}

def mulai_bot(bot_id: int):
    if bot_id in active_bots and active_bots[bot_id].is_alive():
        return True, f"Bot {bot_id} sudah berjalan."
    # ... create and start bot thread
    active_bots[bot_id] = bot_thread

Designed to be elegant, powerful, and flexible â€” whether you're a scalper, swing trader, or a strategy researcher. --- ## ðŸš€ Features - âœ… **Modular Strategy System**: Easily create and plug in your own trading strategies. - âœ… **Comprehensive Backtester**: Test your strategies against historical data with detailed performance metrics and visualizations. - âœ… **Real-Time Analysis**: Live dashboard with data visualization using Chart.js. - âœ… **Adaptive Logic**: Comes with a Hybrid strategy that adapts to trending or ranging markets. - âœ… **Automated Trading**: Full position handling (entry, exit, SL, TP) using bot-specific magic numbers. - âœ… **Persistent Logging**: All activities and trades are logged to a local SQLite database. - âœ… **Modern Web UI**: Clean and responsive dashboard built with Flask and TailwindCSS. - âœ… **Multi-Timeframe Support**: Analyze and trade on any standard timeframe from M1 to D1. - âœ… **Live/Demo Ready**: Tested and ready for both demo and live trading accounts. --- ## ðŸ“¦ Tech Stack - `Python 3.10+` - `Flask` & `TailwindCSS` - `MetaTrader5` Python Integration - `pandas` & `pandas-ta` for data analysis - `Chart.js` for data visualization - `SQLite` for database --- ## ðŸ§  Strategy Examples | Strategy | Description | Best For | |---|---|---| | `Moving Average Crossover` | Classic Golden/Death Cross. | Trending markets (e.g., Indices, XAUUSD). | | `Bollinger Bands Reversion` | Mean reversion based on price touching the bands. | Ranging/Volatile markets (e.g., EURUSD). | | `QuantumBotX Hybrid` | Adaptive strategy using ADX to switch between MA Crossover and Bollinger Bands. | All-weather performance. | --- ## ðŸ“ˆ Roadmap - [ ] **Advanced Strategy**: `MACD_STOCH_FILTER` for more precise, filtered entries. - [ ] **Telegram Notifications**: Get real-time alerts for trades and errors. - [ ] **Portfolio Analytics**: Deeper insights into your trading performance. --- ## ðŸ” Environment Variables (`.env`) Rename `.env.example` to `.env`, and fill in the following: ```env MT5_LOGIN="your_mt5_login" MT5_PASSWORD="your_password" MT5_SERVER="your_broker_server" SECRET_KEY="any_flask_secret_key" DB_NAME=bots.db ``` > **Note:** The API keys for Alpha Vantage, CMC, and Finnhub are deprecated and can be ignored. --- ## ðŸ§ª Local Setup (Dev Mode) 1. **Clone the repository:** ```bash git clone https://github.com/rebarakaz/quantumbotx.git cd quantumbotx ``` 2. **Set up Python virtual environment:** ```bash python -m venv venv # On Windows .\venv\Scripts\activate # On macOS/Linux source venv/bin/activate ``` 3. **Install dependencies:** ```bash pip install -r requirements.txt ``` 4. **Configure your environment:** ```bash cp .env.example .env # Now, edit the .env file with your MT5 credentials ``` 5. **Run the application:** ```bash python run.py ``` > **Important:** You must have the MetaTrader 5 terminal installed and running on the same machine. --- ## âš ï¸ Disclaimer Trading foreign exchange on margin carries a high level of risk and may not be suitable for all investors.
